document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

284F137866AF4977A83C5ABE0076B89A.description:
Participate in a group activity to line up pictures of themselves at various
ages in the correct order.

1AC595412D134C618D8BFDF42E3B7B8B.description: Use vocabulary about time with some accuracy.

68F9B42E3CC94D9EBFA90105D6468C45.description:
Tell about their family histories with some accuracy. For example: “Mommy
lived in Japan before but now she lives here,” “My grampa’s mom used to be
like the people in the book, but then she was free and she had my grampa,”
and “My papa’s family has lived here since always. His gramma and grampa
lived in the house next door!”

DF7E66704AFA469F916A020A4F84D1A9.description:
Tell about things that happened in the past, are happening now in the
present, or will happen in the future with accuracy. For example, “Mommy
lived in Japan before, but now she lives here,” “I’m going to softball
tomorrow night,” and “I’m going to go to kindergarten soon!”

3D6A2BDDF94245E48972C4A7A3E4ABC5.description:
Tell about things that happened in the past. For example: “I used to like
purple, but now I like pink,” “Nana hurt her hip but now she’s all better,” or “I
went to Disney World before.”

C21424F1968C497C824D459B09E4FE48.description:
Tell a familiar adult that they are going on a trip to see their grandmother
because “it’s going to be her birthday” or that they can’t go to gymnastics
tonight because “my teacher called yesterday, and she doesn’t feel good.”

558209CF7E6D4919860605EE4EAFCFC9.description: Put pictures of a story in the order they happened.

03CD3376ECCC4DEA9C360696B4CA416D.description:
Use terms like morning, afternoon, day, and night to talk about times of the
day, with some accuracy.

82CC7A6A556D484AB7132B0D993EE07B.description:
Begin to use terms like yesterday and tomorrow with some accuracy. For
example, saying “Tomorrow I go to Sunday School” on a Friday.

38CF5E3FCC654A1DA130B10CFEEEF532.description:
Imitate familiar home routines during dramatic play, such as singing a lullaby
when putting a baby doll to bed or asking another child to pass out plates
and cups while they “make dinner.”

A2D5BDE5A16B4F65A2567CC464DF7FAE.description: Refer to a picture schedule to find out what will happen today.

D36B427439B345398BCFC909B1AB6E34.description:
Anticipate familiar routines, such as putting away their coat when they come
inside, coming to the snack table after afternoon group time, or brushing
teeth after a meal.

BBC6BED179074FC888BAD007D4FB0338.description: Demonstrate a growing understanding of the passage of time as it impacts their lives.

D4B0487C51FB497C89A4C51BA2ADFC01.description:
Use toys and other materials to make representations of mountains, forests,
streets, and other familiar landmarks during pretend play.

E46A3209A9314B608B74FC13BF9B28DE.description: Use a map to figure out if their home is closer to the park or the school.

C25C09B8BC3C4626AD573E369DDD0816.description: Recite the name of the street they live on and the town they live in.

F3B3EFFA9FDF4276A3379F0041831373.description:
Use terms like left and right when describing where something is,
sometimes.

5992A61221264738AA13797BCF8F0338.description:
Use green and brown tissue paper to represent trees or broken mosaic
pieces to represent a mountain in their artwork.

3EB0D91AFE1445A49913C335C1CDEA04.description:
Show interest in geographical tools, such as globes, maps, and GPS/map
apps on a tablet.

8B01CAC1ADAB449F91694D68AF53D2EC.description:
Recognize and draw pictures of familiar places, geographical features, and
landmarks in their community.

E3DDB76759704E3CB7BE106C5C61DCB2.description: Explain where something is, using terms like near and far away.

23D0A82FA166481B8571812E8C1EFFD3.description: Put a drawing into their own cubby space, most of the time.

81DBE6A2947B49A2BB11A40B22264D5A.description: Say, “The park by my house has swings.”

58A3DEF13D7842B0B267D25314274A01.description: Point out familiar places during a drive or walk around their community.

E41D2E2EC4C945178F8D0B1568BF0C98.description:
Begin to identify, and use location vocabulary to describe, places and physical features in their
environment.

B00C730A10BC41AE9F3D7B0CAEC1AEEE.description:
Ask detailed questions about an animal visiting their learning environment,
sometimes.

2C3C1DAB5DDF4230AA73E86F36FFEC73.description: Track the growth of a plant in their science journal.

451642915EE04837970D47E623036679.description:
Participate in a group activity to wear gloves while carefully collecting
garbage on the playground, sorting items into trash and recycling.

FE771B691DCD4B5385484FE4F1CE3D9D.description:
Participate in a group activity to carefully catch a grasshopper in an insect
habitat, observe the grasshopper, and then let it go again.

7ACBF314DB114AD69EE7155571113C33.description:
Participate in a group activity to track the weather, temperature, or plant
growth over time.

CBB427E340654AA697C2FC3BF7F770F7.description:
With modeling and reminders, put extra paper into a scrap box, and plastic
cups in the recycle bin.

04EC8400D41546999174DBF2F5E24547.description: With modeling and guidance, bring the packaging from their snack to a garbage bin rather than letting it fall on the ground outside.

703DE8DF6E3A484F868D1A86A4BD23E6.description: Explore and learn how to respectfully interact with nature.

513C182BAF034B36AD921EC67C9FA28A.description: Children begin to understand their place and time in the broader world.

3720CA682AFD4B81B382753D78B905CC.description: Explain that they are saving their “birthday money” for a later purchase.

8F75C571992743B48D55060635F15BC6.description: Set aside a project to work on the next day.

9D6F4E4F8B124E099DFE19DDD0CC1EF9.description:
Describe their family members’ jobs with more detail (a general idea of
what they do or where they work), with some prompting, sometimes.

1A9F6861315245DA931D02BC88EA1E72.description:
Share something about their family members’ jobs, with prompting and
support.

F7457BA5CDFA41DEB32D91171ADB7D59.description:
Exchange “goods and services” (food, veterinary care, etc.) for pretend
money during dramatic play.

B9E9BD7DE921473783BB1E68E0BCB8A6.description:
Use costumes and props to explore restaurant, veterinarian, grocery
store, and other jobs with dramatic play.

7173309A554C49E7BA0F4B65888C4624.description:
With guidance, trade a blue dinosaur to another child in exchange for
the red dinosaur they want to play with.

B5E4A550143C479182478725D2EC2690.description:
With guidance and support, agree to share a basket of dinosaur toys
with another child.

D6F20874BDBB4D7380675F63209EA8CA.description:
Develop a growing understanding of value, as well as supply and demand, as they relate to sharing
and trading.

F8030C5700264B59A72B7769FF9E4B4B.description:
Describe how they rely on their family to have their needs met.
For example: “Daddy went grocery shopping” and “Nana has to
work late tonight, but we get to go to the park tomorrow.”

3EEF9B5306BF4F2D80E90143EF7876A3.description:
Recognize the difference between needing something and
wanting it.

E5EC9F8815D0492086495BC5331DA16C.description:
Compare people’s clothing to a dog’s fur – how it keeps them
warm, protected from the sun, etc.

526EA2688D21483B950E483673577A0F.description: Point out that animals need food and water just like people.

5E8902C6C19B4208ABC4A7CB731365D5.description: Help give a pet food and water.

789CBD99F4CF436AB820F6819DB07A3E.description:
Develop a growing understanding of what people need to thrive and the ways people fill
those needs.

0EBAA0C4800C4E80894E60B850DED045.description:
Get their naptime blanket out after they finish lunch,
anticipating the next step in their daily routine.

8429A4B0669E4ED5AFD3EB3135F24CC8.description:
Say, “I can do it,” when a familiar adult is looking for
someone to help with a task.

ED06B459DA9840A1818C4149E7E86DE3.description:
Point out the differences between routines and schedules
at home and at school, or other groups they are part of.

7990EFE3307D4462A63F6735CBE1CD0B.description:
Participate in different routines in different situations, such
as washing hands when they come in from the playground
at school but pulling out a wet wipe to wash hands at the
park.

2B2983EAEEE141ACAD0006DB649E9348.description:
Offer their help to a family member setting the table for a
meal, or a classmate cleaning up.

492689E6B66C453A8CEE1E689B1A54B5.description:
Participate in simple routines such as gathering for group
time, washing hands, or checking on a pet’s food, with and
without reminders.

CB9803D3F9204966976C798BF683E497.description:
Show a growing understanding of and participation with the expectations, boundaries, and
responsibilities in their family, learning environment, and community.

2F7BF2F14FF94930924D3501ADF67D44.description:
Children recognize the value in the contributions they, their families, and
others make to the community.

D22C12DDD63449A781D8007206FD35F7.description:
Bring a Mosaico or other game from their home culture to show and
share with other children.

CF3DC418E3AA4C8CB4F79DABA0902723.description:
Tell an adult visiting for lunchtime that “Charlotte can’t have the
meatballs.”

C6803B8E7E9145B08ED34A9A4AF79A26.description:
Recognize and point out differences between traditions at home and in
other places. For example: “I use chopsticks at home,” or “At home, we
say a prayer before we eat.”

39D0ED5D716545BAA8EF0063F68A5614.description:
In a group discussion about what everyone did over the weekend, tell
about going to Aunt Hazel’s for a birthday.

1A224A620B2B4553A002C3EAEE76CC0E.description:
With support, tell about some of their own family traditions, such as “We
go to shul and say Shabbat shalom” or “Mommy wears a headscarf.”

EA7CF3FE8CBA493A880DDF01AB8115EA.description:
Participate in the routines, customs, and traditions of their family and community, and develops an
awareness of and respect for the ways these can differ across settings, families, and cultures.

250C167F75CE4574B7246248A8FBE9CB.description:
Share stories about what they do with their community group, or as part of a
cultural tradition.

8C683E4F8A6B44A7AA7117D1AC12D773.description:
Say, “I can do it,” when a familiar adult is looking for someone to help with a
task.

F663348EFF3B4A2B92DD936391C7BCC0.description: Tell about what they did at a family gathering.

15DAD2BBC5A94A188A0FB3BFA17B47A9.description:
Offer their help to a family member setting the table for a meal, or a
classmate cleaning up.

6D363E9D71F3485AA4448E437C14DEBC.description:
Mention different groups they belong to in conversation. For example, “I
build with blocks at my preschool,” “My family doesn’t eat that food,” “I like to
play with Sharine and Lucy. They live in my neighborhood.”

321C46B8041A4A12A7BE37CA53E671F7.description: Share a food their family eats on special occasions.

937C9D0C54344AD580713B89B217E01A.description: Tell a familiar adult about their dance teacher.

70B2FAC0C892441597CC89177E07ECA2.description:
Play with blocks while telling about a visit with cousins when they played
with blocks together.

C0DE1DE571794BD581089E0C58198FA4.description:
Demonstrate a growing sense of belonging across their home, their learning environment, and their
community.

56DD49CC1AB04678B1216AE2192611EB.description:
Tell about playing in the backyard with their cousins, or about other family
relationships.

F23D8BD37E92436E845C491EC1071340.description:
Look at a friend’s drawing of their family and have a conversation about the
ways their families are different and the same. “I don’t have a dog like you.
I have an iguana named Princess.” And “Your mama wears a headscarf like
my mama!”

D19192AA1A184346AE88BBB4E5622FE3.description:
Point to people in a photo from a large family gathering. “That’s my Aunt Lily
and Aunt Gigi. This is Grampa Ed and my cousin Maia.”

6B9B3602E70A42BC96158DDE4986B399.description:
When participating in a group discussion about things to do in Fall, describe
their family’s Día de los Muertos traditions.

7E77A8EB5D6248DE9F2F4445C1074471.description:
Draw a picture of their babysitter and say, “I like him. He plays trucks with
me!”

6F61057BA47E482FBFA07EF013BA652B.description:
Share about the work the adult members of their family do. “Daddy goes to
work at the fire station and Nana stays home with me and my sister.”

DA94EE82F52B4061B7D12BEC8A1AF693.description:
Draw a picture of their family and dictate the name of each person so a
familiar adult can label the drawing.

607C1AE34C084E738342ADB98B6FD84A.description: Tell about building a sandcastle with their family.

27733F726F3E469685B7227322A826E2.description: Draw a picture of their family, including themselves.

2A1DFD3511A84AF3A50505E2E0D65069.description:
Hold a family member’s hand and lead them to their learning environment or
group.

77F584874345486B8339BAD29E462F26.description:
Ask a friend, “Is that a picture of your family? This one is a picture of my
moms and my brother.”

E7EDBF53FCCF42D89A4817243B0FB6DF.description:
Recognize themselves as members of a family and become aware of how families are alike and
different.

907EF29ABE8D4E74A35FD791E3C53020.description:
Compare their own family and cultural traditions to others’. For example:
“My family lights candles for Channukah but Laurie’s family has a tree for
Christmas.” Or “I like bacon, but Nyla doesn’t eat pork.”

F3A36C493F8E4129A2A5CAC8DA0D0EDA.description: Tell about and discuss events involving their family members.

BB84EF918FF14BB0A4C545B691DFD3C2.description: Recite their home address and/or phone number.

E57DF4965C4C41E7B54DAF4C090DA94B.description:
With support, identify some of their own and others’ character traits. For
example, “Salim is a good friend. Jordan is nice, too. Kiki talks loud.”

0BCCCF51846D45D4A79528B52725EBC8.description:
Recognize and describe similarities and differences in some of their own and
others’ physical characteristics, such as hair color, age, and relative height.
For example: “I’m taller than Miguel.”

109BB4ECDDA4458694EE3FE4B7C0C7CE.description:
Join in group conversations about children’s preferences in concrete
categories such as food, colors, play areas, etc. “I like playing in the art area.
Sometimes Layla will paint with me, but her favorite is the blocks.”

DB84F7DDB42A410F8E40254659B165C0.description:
With support, recognize the similarities and differences between their own
characteristics and preferences and those of others.

5B8935A911B44A918FDE25936BBEB9FA.description:
Identify some of their own physical characteristics, such as hair color, eye
color, and hair texture or length.

883D3491BE7B43588877240B2C475696.description: Recognize and respond to their own first/given and last/family name.

83CB5B23979347C8B1386C4B20885A7C.description: Recognize themselves as unique individuals and become aware of the uniqueness of others.

20B6C9D502F74DD8A3B5CC816EF998A5.description:
Children understand and respect themselves and others as individuals and as
members of a family, learning environment, and community.
